Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evolution of the Deep South Atlantic Since the Last Interglacial Period Inferred from a Depth Transect of Cape Basin Sediment Cores
Award.AbstractNarration:
There is considerable evidence that the deep ocean plays some role in governing the evolution of Pleistocene ice ages and interglacial periods. Yet after several decades of research, there is still debate over the degree to which sedimentary tracers can distinguish differences in deep ocean circulation between ice age oceans and the modern ocean. This collaborative project will investigate past ocean circulation changes by generating multi-proxy records for several common paleoceanographic tracers (including benthic d18O and d13C, radiocarbon, Cd/Ca, Zn/Ca and B/Ca) for eight time slices over the last glacial-interglacial cycle using cores along a depth transect from the Namibian margin and Cape Basin. These time slices would represent the step in evolution from interglacial state through a full glacial cycle. The research will focus around a series of questions concerning water mass evolution in the Atlantic Ocean, the connection between circulation and carbon cycling, differences between conservative and non-conservative proxies, and the possibility for major boundary condition changes distinct from ocean mixing effects.

Broader impacts:
This project will provide a detailed picture of the mixing between the two principal deep water masses of the world's ocean across a full ice cycle, which will be of widespread use to oceanographers and climate scientists. Funding will support two Ph.D. students and provide significant experience in proxy data collection and interpretation. The project will also serve as a platform for a summer REU fellow and provide support for several undergraduate students to learn research and laboratory techniques. Additionally, funding will help develop a lesson on deep earth circulation through the Deep Earth Academy at Texas A&M University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Circulation of seawater in the deep ocean plays an important role in the global transport of heat and ocean carbon storage, and variations of ocean circulation affect life and geological deposits in the ocean as well as climate. The goal of this project was to better understand the history of ocean circulation in the eastern basin of the South Atlantic during the most recent glacial-interglacial climate cycles, which occurred during the past one hundred and fifty thousand years. Water masses in the South Atlantic intersect the margin of southwest Africa offshore of Namibia, and the marine sediments deposited along this margin show how the circulation of these water masses changed over time. Marine sediments samples from a wide range of water depths (about 550 to 3700 m) were investigated using a number of different analytical techniques. The mineral constituents, physical properties, ages, and chemical compositions of these sediments were determined. Changes in the sediments through time were found to reflect the influences of ocean circulation and regional climate. Fluxes of biogenic calcium carbonate and non-carbonate sediments to the seafloor are greatest at sites where the water depth is shallower than about 1200 m because they receive significant sediment input from the African continent and the Benguela Current upwelling system. At these sites, greater influx of wind-blown material from the continent during the glacial times is the primary driver of glacial-interglacial variations in the sediment deposition. Temporal variability in sediment deposition is depth-dependent at deeper sites. Lower calcium carbonate accumulation rates during glacial times at sites corresponding to the water depth range of about 1800 to 2600 m suggest the boundary between northern-sourced North Atlantic Deep Water and underlying southern-sourced Lower Circumpolar Deep Water / Antarctic Bottom Water shoaled relative to its position during interglacial times. A significant glacial-interglacial difference in the accumulation rate of calcium carbonate is not observed at sites deeper than about 2600 m that were always bathed by southern-sourced deep waters. The project’s reconstructions of the properties and geometry of glacial water masses and the history of wind-blown sediments contribute directly to our understanding of Atlantic Ocean thermohaline circulation and the climate of southern Africa. These results also provide valuable constraints for coupled ocean-atmosphere numerical simulations of ocean circulation and climate processes. Information acquired by the project is disseminated via presentations at various public venues, journal articles, and databases; and remaining sediment sample material is archived and available for use by future researchers. This project contributed to the development of human resources: it provided science participation/learning opportunities for a number of undergraduate students, and it supported the education/training of several graduate students who are now employed as environmental scientists.
